metadata.title: The dominant role of oxygen in modulating tyrosine-containing peptide self-evolving pathways: Bioluminescence or thermoregulation

referenceMentions.context: 32 ns, confirming that the emission was fluorescence (Figure 2e).([14]) Notably, compared to pure water, D-ZY shows no significant photothermal effect (Figure S6), confirming that these dityrosinecontaining derivatives are photoluminescent rather than photothermal materials.

metadata.abstractText: In diverse biological systems, the chemical evolution of tyrosine to melanin or dityrosine is extremely crucial for the formation of crosslinked proteins and thus for the realization of their structural, biological, and photoactive functionalities; however, the predominant factor that determines the pathways of this chemical evolution has not been revealed. Herein, we demonstrate, on tyrosine-containing amino acid derivatives, peptides, and proteins that the selective oxidation of tyrosine to produce melanin or dityrosine can be readily realized by manipulating the oxygen concentration in the reaction system. This oxygen-dependent pathway selection resembles the selective chemical evolution of tyrosine in anaerobic and aerobic microorganisms. The resulting melaninand dityrosine-containing nanomaterials reproduce key functions of their natural counterparts with respect to their photothermal and photoluminescent characteristics, respectively. This work reveals the plausible role of oxygen in the chemical evolution of tyrosine and provides a versatile strategy for the rational design of tyrosine-based multifunctional biomaterials. As key biochemical monomers in the process leading toward the first living organisms, amino acids are believed to be abundant on the prebiotic Earth due to the ease of their abiotic synthesis under primitive conditions. An appealing yet unsolved question is how modern proteins with distinct functions were generated from amino acids through prebiotic and biosynthetic pathways. The formation and functionalization of proteins involve not only the condensation of amino acids and self-assembly of the resulting peptides, but also the chemical evolution of amino acids. A typical example of such chemical evolution is the oxidation of tyrosine to melanin and dityrosine, producing crosslinked proteins. These crosslinked proteins play important roles in realizing biological functionalities of living organisms. For instance, dityrosine networks formed in the guts of insects are responsible for their decreased epithelial immunity to commensal bacteria, whereas melanin promotes thermoregulation for numerous animals. Inspired by the complicated functions of natural tyrosine derivatives, researchers have increasingly interested in the chemical oxidation of tyrosine to produce crosslinked groups. Either melanin or dityrosine was synthesized by using various strategies, such as photochemical reactions, Fenton-like reactions, and enzymatic reactions. These strategies have been demonstrated to be productive toward the development of tyrosine-based materials in many areas, such as drug delivery, tissue engineering, and biomineralization. However, the selective manipulation of the reaction pathways of tyrosine is still challenging, and thus, the mechanisms underlying the formation of melanin or dityrosine have not been clearly revealed. Therefore, new strategies for precisely controlling the pathways of tyrosine oxidation are highly desired. Scheme 1. Illustration of the selective oxidation of tyrosine to produce melaninor dityrosine-based functional materials by manipulating the oxygen concentration in a system. The resulting melanin-based materials show typical photothermal properties while the dityrosine-based materials show photoluminescent property. In living organisms, the selective production of melanin or dityrosine from tyrosine is induced by biochemical cascades involving peroxidases and oxidases. Intriguingly, microorganisms that produce melanin or dityrosine grow in distinct environments. Dityrosine is usually observed in anaerobic microorganisms, whereas microorganisms that can produce melanin by using tyrosine as the precursor are mainly found in aerobic environments. Inspired by the environmentrelated chemical evolution of tyrosine in living microorganisms, we herein investigated the impact of oxygen concentration on tyrosine oxidation in aqueous solutions with the aim of realizing the selective production of melanin or dityrosine by a straightforward strategy and providing plausible mechanisms for the chemical evolution of tyrosine-based biomaterials. By using three tyrosine-containing biomolecules as the reactants, we demonstrated that the oxidation of tyrosine driven by light irradiation to produce melanin or dityrosine involves two competitive pathways and that pathway selection can be readily X. Ren, Prof. Q. Zou, Dr. C. Yuan, Dr. R. Chang, Dr. R. Xing, Prof. X.
